column4: why are packages typically held back when running apt-get upgrade?
packages should not typically be held back. if something is held back, it's usually because there's a problem.
so how do I debug that?
mm, depends. what packages are being held back?
hmm, that's really wierd. sorry, i don't know much about apt. the #debian crew might know more, they tend to be more technically adept >.<
thanks
try typing this: aptitude unhold *
not sure I want that to work...I'm concerned with why it was done in the first place now...something must've broken and that looks like a quick fix
well then i don't understand what you want us to help you with.
you want to unhold everything except certain packages, but you don't know which ones?

if this is an important box, like a corporate server or something, my suggestion is to just not upgrade. if you need the upgrades for some reason (most importantly security), then unhold * and upgrade. if something breaks, fix it, or roll it back.
sorry, just trying to figure out why it would be held back...
you're exactly right though.
you can check the dpkg log files and the sudo audit file to see what apt commands have been used
cat /var/log/auth.log|grep apt|less
cat /var/log/auth.log.0|grep apt|less
cat /var/log/auth.log.*.gz|gunzip|grep apt|less
you can try grepping hold instead, might help
nothing there that's interesting...
I think it's a dist-upgrade issue...
no problem
